newsitem.title: USA: New class of antibiotics may offer hope to patients.
newsitem.headline: New class of antibiotics may offer hope to patients.

text.p: Scientists combining natural and synthetic products have created a new class of antibiotics that could offer hope to patients resistant to current antibiotics, the journal Science reported Thursday.
But the new antibiotics, the first developed in many years, require clinical trials before their full potential can be known, Science reported.
Moreover, the tediously complicated and expensive process needed to produce these new drugs could prevent them from becoming commerically viable, the magazine reported.

The team of scientists who wrote the magazine article on their work said they were able to tinker with polyketides, the chief components of many important drugs including the popular antibiotic erythromycin.
The authors blocked a natural polyketide process and substituted synthetic molecules at certain steps.
A companion article in Science described the technique as a way to "hijack" chemical paths within bacterial cells to create antibiotics.

"The technique still has a long way to go before it's ready to produce molecules for market," one antibiotics researcher, Leonard Katz of Abbott Laboratories in Illinois, said in the companion article.
The research is part of a push to find new versions of antibiotics as ever more strains of bacteria develop resistance to conventional drugs.
